<Link id="l01205" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1205"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This function is used to enforce the topological node id property</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01206" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1206"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// leveraged during instruction selection. Before the selection process all</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01207" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1207"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// nodes are given a non-negative id such that all nodes have a greater id than</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01208" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1208"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// their operands. As this holds transitively we can prune checks that a node N</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01209" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1209"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is a predecessor of M another by not recursively checking through M&#39;s</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01210" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1210"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// operands if N&#39;s ID is larger than M&#39;s ID. This significantly improves</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01211" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1211"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// performance of various legality checks (e.g. IsLegalToFold / UpdateChains).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01212" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1212"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01213" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1213"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// However, when we fuse multiple nodes into a single node during the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01214" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1214"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// selection we may induce a predecessor relationship between inputs and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01215" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1215"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// outputs of distinct nodes being merged, violating the topological property.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01216" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1216"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Should a fused node have a successor which has yet to be selected,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01217" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1217"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// our legality checks would be incorrect. To avoid this we mark all unselected</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01218" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1218"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// successor nodes, i.e. id != -1, as invalid for pruning by bit-negating (x =&gt;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01219" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1219"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (-(x+1))) the ids and modify our pruning check to ignore negative Ids of M.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01220" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1220"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We use bit-negation to more clearly enforce that node id -1 can only be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01221" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1221"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// achieved by selected nodes. As the conversion is reversable to the original</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01222" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1222"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Id, topological pruning can still be leveraged when looking for unselected</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01223" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1223"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// nodes. This method is called internally in all ISel replacement related</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01224" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1224"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// functions.</span></CodeLine>
